Award.AwardTitle: Developing Magnetic, Optical and Catalytic Applications of Metallacrowns
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Vincent L. Pecoraro of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Michigan will develop new classes of metal complexes known as metallacrowns (containing lanthanides, transition and alkali earth metal ions) with interesting magnetic, luminescent and catalytic properties. The goal of this research is to exploit the characteristics of these metallacrowns to make complexes that will reduce the volume necessary to store information magnetically, that may be used as in vivo and in vitro luminescent agents for the imaging of chemical and biological samples and to prepare new multimetallic catalysts for fine chemicals synthesis. This work has been used for the development of laboratory undergraduate courses and likely will engage both undergraduate and possibly high school student participation. Also, this work is used as an example of creativity in scholarship in an undergraduate course on this subject at the University of Michigan.

Metallacrowns (MC) are metallamacrocycles that have since garnered considerable attention for their structural versatility and metal-rich topology. Of particular interest is a vast series of 3d-4f heterometallic MCs that contain a transition metal ion and a lanthanide (Ln3+)ion. The main objectives of this proposal are to exploit the potential of this type of MC for applications in 1) molecular recognition and catalysis, 2) optical materials for luminescence and non-linear optics (NLO) and 3) molecular magnetism. Materials produced in this work have great potential to find commercial use. Substrate specific catalytic materials have potential to improve synthetic processes in the chemical industry, while MC research on magnetic materials has the potential to revolutionize data storage and enhance the understanding of magnetic phenomena. Lumiphores based on MCs containing Zn(II) or Ga(III) and Ln3+ ions are particularly promising for near-IR biological imaging and long range fiber optic telecommunications while application as NLO solids are also promising.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes from NSF CHE 1361779: Developing Magnetic, Optical, and Catalytic Applications of Metallacrowns (MCs) have been both productive and fascinating. During the course of this grant, 9 papers have been published and 2 patents have been filed. Landmark results that demonstrate stronger understanding in the fields of single molecule magnets (SMMs), magnetic refrigeration, lanthanide (Ln) based luminescent imaging, and molecular recognition have been achieved. For SMMS, a newly synthesized di-Ln complex showed a relaxation pathway featuring weak interaction between two dysprosium ions, which is an important discovery towards the development of faster computational technology using qubits. Additionally, the yttrium/dysprosium analog of this molecule represents the current record holder for the size of an effective barrier to relaxation for metallacrowns. Another study investigated the relationship of carboxylate anions in manganese MCs, where the basicity of the carboxylate correlates with the absence or presence of SMM behavior.  Weaker bases, such as salicylate, had observable SMM behavior, while stronger bases such as trimethylacetate did not. Lastly, an iron-based MC was characterized for its magnetic cooling properties and represents the possibility of an inexpensive, earth abundant and low molecular weight material that could perform as a coolant at extremely low temperatures.  This compound could have applications for gas condensation, especially for use in space vehicles.

Metallacrowns have shown massive potential for use as Ln-based luminescent imaging probes. A gallium based MC was reported to have the ability to sensitize most of the Ln, with emission ranging from the visible to the near-infrared (NIR). This is not a common observation in this field and has few other examples. This complex also holds the record for emission with ytterbium, a promising ion for in vivo imaging. In addition, new zinc-based metallacrowns were shown to be able to simultaneously fix and image cervical cancer cells, as well as selectively imaging cells that have undergone necrotic death. Cell fixation is a process where a cell is converted into a “life-like” state so that internal structures are preserved during the imaging process. Currently, these are separate procedures, but the zinc MC may do both simultaneously, which significantly reduces the time and effort to prepare a sample for imaging. The selective imaging of necrotic cells is useful since these cells release toxins which are harmful to neighboring cells. The current dye used for this purpose is propidium iodide (PI), an organic chromophore. Much like PI, the metallacrown is able to selectively image necrotic cells without concerns of cytotoxicity to living cells; however, the MC does so without photobleaching and has a much larger separation between the energy of excitation and emission. These advantages make the metallacrown easier to work with for longer experiments with better signal to noise ratios.

Progress towards the use of MCs in catalytic applications has been made using “hand-shaped” complexes, designed to have one face selectively recognize dicarboxylate guest molecules. Recognition of specific molecules is an important checkpoint on the way towards building selective catalytic agents, which can be widely used in synthetic chemistry for pharmaceutical and agricultural applications. Gadolinium-based metallacrowns were shown to form nanocapsules when two MCs associate via interactions between hydrophobic carbon-based side chains. These studies showed that the driving forces directing MC-guest-MC complex formation is dependent on guest length, and proved for the first time that their formation in solution is a consequence of host-guest interaction.

Finally, a new class of permanently porous coordination polymer (PCP) was synthesized using copper metallacrowns as bridging structural subunits. These PCPs formed 2D sheets that exhibited good N2 and CO2 gas adsorption. Guest-responsive properties of metallacrown-based frameworks may be exploited for unique applications as luminescent sensors, advanced magnetic materials, or porous catalytic agents.

The development of these new metallacrowns in magnetic, imaging, and catalytic applications represent a significant impact directly beneficial to society. However, the broader impacts of MCs are not restricted to the development of these applications. During the course of this grant, one PhD student has graduated, and one post-doc was trained. Three other graduate students in the process of obtaining their PhD have also been funded by this grant. In addition, one undergraduate and one high school student have gotten a chance to work on this project and gather laboratory experience. This project has also seen a significant amount of international collaboration with work done by groups in Italy, France, Poland, and Ukraine. International mobility of researchers aided by this grant has resulted in excellent intellectual exchange of ideas. However, the collaboration has not been restricted to international laboratories, but also exists with smaller universities in the United States including primarily undergraduate institutions. These collaborations allow for researchers and their students at these smaller schools to have access to instrumentation that allows for unique learning opportunities for the students.


Last Modified: 11/02/2017
Modified by: Vincent L Pecoraro

During the course of this grant, 9 papers have been published and 2 patents have been filed. Landmark results that demonstrate stronger understanding in the fields of single molecule magnets (SMMs), magnetic refrigeration, lanthanide (Ln) based luminescent imaging, and molecular recognition have been achieved. Another study investigated the relationship of carboxylate anions in manganese MCs, where the basicity of the carboxylate correlates with the absence or presence of SMM behavior.
